work.p: This manuscript is similar to another manuscript that relates to the following lines, which appeared in the 1860 poem "Proto-Leaf," eventually titled "Starting from Paumanok": "Behold! the body includes and is the meaning, the main concern—and includes and is the Soul; / Whoever you are! how superb and how divine is your body, or any part of it" (1860, p. 17) and "All hold spiritual joys, and afterward loosen them, / How can the real body ever die, and be buried?" (1860, p. 16).

a machine readable transcription

notesStmt.note: This manuscript was probably composed before the Civil War, when Whitman was most actively pursuing his role as the poet of the body.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: The Body
bibl.orgName: Trent Collection of Whitmaniana, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

lg.head: The Body—
lg.l:
Why what did do you
suppose is the Body?

Do you suppose this
matter that has always
existed—this meat,
bread, fruit, that is
eaten, is the body?

No, those are but the
visible parts of the
body, materials that
have existed in some
way for mbillions of years—
now entering into the
form of the body

But there is the real
body too, not visible
